$(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"arrow-up\"></div>\r\n                                <li><a class=\"addthis_button_email\"><span>Email</span></a></li>\r\n                                <li><a class=\"addthis_button_twitter\"><span>Twitter</span></a></li>\r\n                                <li><a class=\"addthis_button_facebook\"><span>Facebook</span></a></li>\r\n                                <li><a class=\"addthis_button_compact\"><span>More</span></a></li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                    <div class=\"toolbar-search\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SitePageHeader widget-instance-OUP_ArticleToolbarSearchBox\">\n        \r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"dropdown-panel-wrap\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-search-dropdown\">\r\n        <div class=\"mobile-search-inner-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                    <div id=\"MobileMicrositeSearch\" class=\"mobile-microsite-search\">\r\n                        <label for=\"mobile-navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">Navbar Search Filter</label>\r\n                        <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"mobile-navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                            <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n<option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\">This issue</option><option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\">All  Monthly Notices of the Royal      </optgroup>\r\n                        </select>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                        <label for=\"MobileMicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">Mobile Microsite Search Term</label>\r\n                        <input class=\"mobile-search-input mobile-microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" placeholder=\"Search\" id=\"MobileMicrositeSearchTerm\">\r\n\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MobileMicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"mobile-microsite-search-icon mobile-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>        </div>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nUniversity of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f476%2f1%2f663%2f4833689\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=112872891 id=\"112872891\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery of a new gravitationally lensed quasar (double) from the Optical Gravitational Lensing Experiment (OGLE) identified inside the \u223c670deg<sup>2</sup> area encompassing the Magellanic Clouds. The source was selected as one of \u223c60 \u2018red <em>W</em>1\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>W</em>2\u2019 mid-infrared objects from <em>WISE</em> and having a significant amount of variability in OGLE for both two (or more) nearby sources. This is the first detection of a gravitational lens, where the discovery is made \u2018the other way around\u2019, meaning we first measured the time delay between the two lensed quasar images of \u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221276 \u2009d (90\u2009per\u2009cent CL), with the median <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub> \u2248 \u2212102 \u2009d (in the observer frame), and where the fainter image B lags image A. The system consists of the two quasar images separated by 1.5\u2009arcsec on the sky, with <em>I</em> \u2248 20.0\u2009mag and <em>I</em> \u2248 19.6\u2009mag, respectively, and a lensing galaxy that becomes detectable as <em>I</em> \u2248 21.5\u2009mag source, 1.0\u2009arcsec from image A, after subtracting the two lensed images. Both quasar images show clear AGN broad emission lines at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.16 in the New Technology Telescope spectra. The spectral energy distribution (SED) fitting with the fixed source redshift provided the estimate of the lensing galaxy redshift of <em>z</em> \u2248 0.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2 (90\u2009per\u2009cent CL), while its type is more likely to be elliptical (the SED-inferred and lens-model stellar mass is more likely present in ellipticals) than spiral (preferred redshift by the lens model).</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: observational&quot;\">methods: observational</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: general&quot;\">quasars: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=112872893 id=\"112872893\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lensing is a powerful tool; acting as a natural telescope it can potentially allow astronomical observations to reach smaller and fainter objects than would otherwise be observable (Schneider, Ehlers &amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Schneider <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). In strong lensing, a massive foreground galaxy or cluster deflects the light from a background object, resulting in multiple images of the distant source, that is typically magnified by a factor of 10. This provides a wide range of applications of the lensing phenomenon. Lensing analyses support fundamental open questions in astrophysics and cosmology, and have been used to investigate the dark matter density profiles of lensing galaxies (e.g. Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Pooley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), substructures (e.g. Dalal &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Kochanek &amp; Dalal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), the evolution of galaxies (e.g. Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Kostrzewa-Rutkowska et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Oldham et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and the properties of dark energy (e.g. Link &amp; Pierce <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Zhu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), just to mention a few.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitationally lensed quasars with measured time delays between the multiple images provide a straightforward and competitive approach to determining the Hubble constant, entirely independent of the local distance ladder, and allow us to study the expansion history of the Universe. The time delay method was proposed by Refsdal (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>), 15\u2009yr before the discovery of the first strong lensing system, Q0957\u00a0+\u00a0561, in 1979 (Walsh, Carswell &amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>). Time delays in gravitationally lensed quasar light curves of different images depend on the gravitational potential of the lensing galaxy and the cosmological distances between the observer, the lens, and the source. In the past few years, there have been many attempts to measure the Hubble constant and other cosmological parameters with increasing precision and accuracy from time delays (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The time delay studies require not only detailed models for the mass profile of the main lens but also taking into account any matter structures along the line of sight (Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Also recently, long time monitored systems were used to determine the Hubble constant with a precision below 5\u2009per cent (Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Furthermore, in multiple quasar images, we may observe the microlensing effect caused by the stars of the lens (e.g. Wambsganss, Paczynski &amp; Schneider <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>; Wambsganss &amp; Paczynski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). This provides stringent constraints on the morphologies of the neighbourhood of black holes in lensed quasars, for example, kinematics and geometric structure in quasar broad emission-line regions (Guerras et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Braibant et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Detailed studies of the accretion discs showed that their sizes are robustly larger than expectations from the thin disc theory and the temperature profile seems to be steeper than expected (Bate, Webster &amp; Wyithe <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>); however, opposite results have also been reported (Poindexter, Morgan &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Because the microlensing effect is also sensitive to the fraction of mass enclosed in stars to dark matter halo mass close to lensed images, at the same time we obtain the stellar composition of the lens galaxies (Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>). While microlensing of lensed quasar images has numerous applications to study the AGN physics, on the other hand, it affects the light curves of quasar images, producing problems in the accurate time delay estimation, and, in turn, introducing biases in the characterization of lens systems (Tie &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). However, recently several algorithms were applied to take into account microlensing in the time delay measurements (e.g. Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are less than two hundred strongly lensed quasars known to date, because (1) they are intrinsically very rare objects and (2) they are discovered by various techniques, each having a number of biases. Considering that we search for lensed sources blended with the light of the lens galaxy, the problem of the deflector's flux contribution impedes the lensed quasar hunt. Systematic searches of gravitationally lensed quasars have been conducted within several surveys, for example, by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and the Dark Energy Survey (DES). Recently, several techniques were explored to search for lensed quasar systems, for example, identification of spectroscopically confirmed quasars and searching for nearby objects of similar colours (large separation systems) or spectroscopically confirmed quasars with extended morphology (small separation systems) (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), selection of lensed quasars using an image subtraction method as they are time variable sources (Kochanek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006a</a>; Lacki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), data mining and mashine learning techniques with a combination of colour cuts and model-based selection (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), Gaussian mixture models of colours (Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), identifying candidate systems of red galaxies with multiple neighbouring blue objects (Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and variability studies of quasars (Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">One of the primary goals of the Optical Gravitational Lensing Experiment (OGLE) \u2013 a long-term sky-variability survey (Udalski, Szyma\u0144ski &amp; Szyma\u0144ski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) \u2013 has been monitoring of selected gravitational lenses. Since 1997, OGLE has performed a continuous, long-term monitoring of the gravitational lens QSO 2237+0305 (Udalski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), where the resulting homogeneous OGLE data set is the most extensive photometric coverage of this source, spanning now two decades and showing numerous unique microlensing effects in this extraordinary object. For the second monitored system, HE 1104\u20131805, the time delay of 157\u00a0\u00b1\u00a021 \u2009d between the light curves of the two images was determined using the photometric data collected between years 1997 and 2002 (Wyrzykowski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present the discovery of the first lensed quasar found in the OGLE data set covering the Magellanic System, the area that has been regularly monitored since 2010. Inside the observing area of about 670deg<sup>2</sup> around the Magellanic Clouds to the photometric depth of <em>I</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a021\u2009mag, statistically there should exist about 10 lensed QSO systems, both doubles and quads (Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Finding all of them in a search is difficult as the detection efficiency is rarely high, mainly due to the fact that quasar variability amplitude becomes buried in the photometric noise for objects fainter than <em>I</em> \u2248 20\u2009mag. This is true in our search, where we combined the OGLE optical data with the mid-IR (mid-infrared) Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (<em>WISE</em>) data, and searched for the intrinsic optical quasar variability (in particular time lags) in OGLE counterparts to \u2018red\u2019 mid-IR sources, without prior spectroscopic analysis. The details of our search and results will be presented in subsequent sections.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce our data sample and present selection method, then describe the lensed quasar candidate (that we subsequently confirm) in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we discuss results of modelling and lens and source properties. The paper is concluded in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. Throughout this paper we assume a flat \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) concordance cosmological model of the Universe with parameters <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda = 0.7$|\u2060</span>, \u03a9<sub>M</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, <em>h</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.70.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=112872901 id=\"112872901\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 THE OGLE SURVEY AND LENSED QUASARS DETECTION STRATEGY</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=112872902 id=\"112872902\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 The OGLE variability survey</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The key data used in this work were collected during the fourth phase of the OGLE project (hereafter OGLE-IV), between the years 2010 and 2017, with the 1.3-m Warsaw telescope located at Las Campanas Observatory, Chile, operated by the Carnegie Institution for Science. The telescope is equipped with a 32 chip mosaic CCD camera, with a total field of view of 1.4deg<sup>2</sup> (Udalski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The entire area of the Magellanic Clouds region is covered by 475 OGLE-IV fields that amounts to about 670deg<sup>2</sup>. Only two filters <em>I</em> and <em>V</em> band have been used by OGLE-IV. About 90\u2009per cent observations were carried out in the <em>I</em> band with magnitude range from 13 to 21.5\u2009mag. The number of collected epochs varies between 100 and 700, and observations of a given field are repeated every 2\u20134\u2009d. The photometry was obtained using the difference image analysis (DIA) method, as implemented by Wo\u017aniak (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=112872904 id=\"112872904\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Lensed quasar candidates</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since 2010, The Magellanic Quasars Survey (MQS) has increased the number of quasars known behind the Magellanic Clouds by almost an order of magnitude using the OGLE-III data (Koz\u0142owski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). It was then a natural consequence to perform a similar extensive search of quasar candidates in the increased OGLE-IV area of the Magellanic System (Koz\u0142owski et\u00a0al. in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The primary sample of quasar candidates was obtained by locating all objects in the <em>WISE</em> survey (Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Cutri &amp; et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) fulfilling any of the mid-IR colours criteria for quasars proposed by Stern et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and Assef et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), then cross-matching them with objects in the OGLE data base, and finally performing a variability analysis of the OGLE objects, as a result isolating a sample of quasar candidates (\u223c15\u2009000 objects).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We used this sample of quasar candidates in further identification of lensed quasar candidates. First, we investigated their environments within a radius of <em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a06\u2009arcsec (approximately W1 <em>WISE</em> FWHM) to identify neighbouring objects in the OGLE data base. Of the 15\u2009000 sources, 63 objects turned out to be \u2018our early\u2019 lens candidates based on the similar rms. in the light curves. Next, for each such a lens candidate (now two or more neighbouring objects), we visually compared both their colour and variability properties. The highest probability candidates were required to have similar variability patterns in both images (and so plausibly the time delay) as reported by the J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> software (Zu, Kochanek &amp; Peterson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Zu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). We also used a dedicated DIA (to prevent \u2018ghost\u2019 variability in the neighbour caused by the true variable object \u2013 we created two images, where we stacked a number of images when the quasar is bright and when it is faint, and then subtracted them to check if the residua due to flux change appear on both locations). Three most promising candidates were observed spectroscopically with the New Technology Telescope (NTT), of which only one turned out to be a genuine lensing system (the other two are unlensed quasar+star pairs, presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>). The false positive rate might be lower by, first, a visual inspection of both the light curves and difference images (ghosts), and then by the spectral energy distribution (SED) fitting. This method allowed for a straightforward identification of the lensed quasar candidate system without extensive spectroscopic observations.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=112872908 id=\"112872908\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 THE LENS SYSTEM</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fulfilling the requirements from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, the candidate considered in this paper had to have \u2018red\u2019 <em>WISE</em> colours (<em>W</em>1\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>W</em>2\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.8\u2009mag from Stern et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a> or a combination of <em>W</em>1\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>W</em>2 and <em>W</em>2 data from Assef et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) but also two optical counterparts well separated on the sky, both showing similar photometric variability, albeit allowed to be shifted in time. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, we present the postage-stamp cutouts for the candidate images A and B, at (RA, Dec.) =(02:18:12.34, \u221273:35:35.8) and (02:18:12.47, \u221273:35:37.2), respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"112872910\" scrollto-destination=\"112872910\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=1YatCzVxLNw61101FBjRQfZ8zA7s91GNLVghfhB8WU43ZuSj4YD7qKvlha6~vQ2ZZKGdca2YVY0~aFYLwXANogxR2iHxsH~HkhmM4mjb7TkMkDOLhh2Hc7kw5Mq7ofKqm0exopAaAjzAj96FjksgC6CVMBZ8L0NYEsqRXT4TQ0eCU7yf6RZsRILuoMBeidhiJGVc99kqka~aq8-kNbJPvO0548iEv6Qvjs8zhVd0oGEWRUwhQe-sBuTPH3qon5qQ-vQ4CQozL~GheEtwwvEAeByqyH4sHvZ0NTP1TVfK9LnAQdTaFhWdl8OOuHfDBomo4EQNs~KWqkDn0lGvVI-ybw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The OGLE lensed quasar as seen in OGLE (top panels) and GROND (bottom panels) is shown. The two lensed quasar images are marked in the top left-hand panel, where A (B) is the brighter (fainter) image. They are separated by 1.5\u2009arcsec and are readily resolvable in the best-seeing OGLE frames of 0.7\u2009arcsec. The top right-hand panel shows the colour composition of I- and V-band frames. The bottom row presents g\u2033r\u2033i\u2033z\u2033JHK GROND observations (from the left- to right-hand panel). The lens galaxy becomes visible as a blend to image B in the infrared data. The bottom row presents <em>g</em>\u2033<em>r</em>\u2033<em>i</em>\u2033<em>z</em>\u2033<em>JHK</em> GROND observations (from the left- to right-hand panel). The lens galaxy becomes visible as a blend to image B in the infrared data. All panels cover approximately 8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup>. North is up and east is to the left-hand side.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=112872911 id=\"112872911\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Spectroscopic confirmation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtained a low resolution spectrum of our candidate with the ESO Faint Object Spectrograph and Camera (EFOSC2) on the 3.58-m Ritchey-Chr\u00e9tien NTT on 2016 September 27. The spectrum of 300\u2009s was taken with a 1.2\u2009arcsec slit, aligned to contain both objects, and using the 13 grism, which gives a wavelength range of 3685 to 9315\u2009\u00c5. The data were binned by factors of 2 along the slit and in the spectral direction. This setup yields a dispersion of 5.54\u2009\u00c5 per pixel and a full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of 21.24\u2009\u00c5. The seeing ranged between 0.5\u20130.6\u2009arcsec. The pair of images in the candidate system was completely resolved. The 2D spectrum was reduced by fitting two Gaussians and extracting 1D spectrum. The confirmation spectrum is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Several common AGN broad emission lines (Ly\u03b1, Si\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>, C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>) at the redshift of <em>z<sub>S</sub></em>\u00a0=\u00a02.16 are present. We were unable to recognize any features from a potential lensing galaxy, simply because it was expected to be too faint in this wavelength range (see SED in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"112872913\" scrollto-destination=\"112872913\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=M2dM-2PTOgeEvW6wgMGLZ1PraOxpHlSvei4vBNuVe4QUMmY1HdTntarPx3PmD34o71qMJ3MlwACw2u6OY9Qgi86eMwN~-0n9CvIxpZiwx1QRxJYsU8lTJMa7w-JVqVNZSny17vCxfcRTf6XfvRvHOo8h9tPxEzRDVAuB9t9cGnG7JiPytF0szEFHvByC~5THt94q~HUGfAsQmtNqbkyxaVqbE-AV9TSVTrgUHHLCw13qVphRh38dGBcwIQ8QOrVQw70pFTlKFpQs8wkbPeiAcwGhrWTREpqbIm8GbFj5ja3mc~F0meW2wGk49GBO87wplZzjaJmlReYHJShXx0CUpQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"NTT spectra of the two images (A in red, B in blue) of the lensed quasar. For comparison, in black, we also show a composite AGN spectrum from Vanden Berk et\u00a0al. (2001). The source redshift is zS\u00a0=\u00a02.16. Four common quasar emission lines are marked with the vertical dotted lines and labelled at the top.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872913/sty259fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872913\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=2vhhPc5vRsOSTdaMr7INql7I3p8PGFJ39MvJAS1i0UYQfo--BYP1Z4--w7FnJDeugYGsbN4H9s7hLE1QnsqMGL8BfWeoU6LJNCfjKttIHT~duimikuH2PWpmLcaGt50mAxcwvuPuJuUtLLjZ6jw0K-NbKOjTq92ZtFheg1Z8P3dMwOf6dhkSyBX0xVhyOMigG1IqV1K11z8zsNAqB5LJdgIHXo~XrXP2UXyoIOn1Nc-C6Yg2SsnhXUuGmckQzV4x5vcI1E9rRe8SjmnSpYvBlGVjP2p8Y2wgSK-t6pOGyt7ceiwAXxyUJ9un6FMFSeDk3BcOWBYImok4i5XfdviEpg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872913&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">NTT spectra of the two images (A in red, B in blue) of the lensed quasar. For comparison, in black, we also show a composite AGN spectrum from Vanden Berk et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). The source redshift is <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.16. Four common quasar emission lines are marked with the vertical dotted lines and labelled at the top.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=M2dM-2PTOgeEvW6wgMGLZ1PraOxpHlSvei4vBNuVe4QUMmY1HdTntarPx3PmD34o71qMJ3MlwACw2u6OY9Qgi86eMwN~-0n9CvIxpZiwx1QRxJYsU8lTJMa7w-JVqVNZSny17vCxfcRTf6XfvRvHOo8h9tPxEzRDVAuB9t9cGnG7JiPytF0szEFHvByC~5THt94q~HUGfAsQmtNqbkyxaVqbE-AV9TSVTrgUHHLCw13qVphRh38dGBcwIQ8QOrVQw70pFTlKFpQs8wkbPeiAcwGhrWTREpqbIm8GbFj5ja3mc~F0meW2wGk49GBO87wplZzjaJmlReYHJShXx0CUpQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"NTT spectra of the two images (A in red, B in blue) of the lensed quasar. Four common quasar emission lines are marked with the vertical dotted lines and labelled at the top.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872913/sty259fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872913\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=2vhhPc5vRsOSTdaMr7INql7I3p8PGFJ39MvJAS1i0UYQfo--BYP1Z4--w7FnJDeugYGsbN4H9s7hLE1QnsqMGL8BfWeoU6LJNCfjKttIHT~duimikuH2PWpmLcaGt50mAxcwvuPuJuUtLLjZ6jw0K-NbKOjTq92ZtFheg1Z8P3dMwOf6dhkSyBX0xVhyOMigG1IqV1K11z8zsNAqB5LJdgIHXo~XrXP2UXyoIOn1Nc-C6Yg2SsnhXUuGmckQzV4x5vcI1E9rRe8SjmnSpYvBlGVjP2p8Y2wgSK-t6pOGyt7ceiwAXxyUJ9un6FMFSeDk3BcOWBYImok4i5XfdviEpg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872913&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">NTT spectra of the two images (A in red, B in blue) of the lensed quasar. Four common quasar emission lines are marked with the vertical dotted lines and labelled at the top.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"112872914\" scrollto-destination=\"112872914\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=k-JvgBeUkJk6-KZ7OKIc-JdkgIt8HBof8jnmFNFmqW-gYYnKNk8y9iRDbtinhOW0g5qr6x8~WhSgVE0pV-xcwX4ea56tWO0aqpSvZKj1dOCTqY2KIAMl2Z128wA04Z3wEThYFs~GeCDjC4Fe4v069uu9v2~UttUUIFZ1ju8E5UwlWenm3ZNgGgZYioJPpdomvh6cKjIw8gml~sPEFACkXYSY0sUmVTnoK5mVxIwOFRxrlz1jeVpBHrZP1-EibAOIc23YMeNvhN2phrSg2XheQIXGLF1NjJkvqz28QpVUxW6YiXPXzGYc0mfMrg9tKj19cvfYShprKt2Vrb5lcaKAcw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED of the OGLE lens system (top panel) and the \u03c72 distribution for the lens redshift (bottom panel). Top panel: the black, red, and blue points come from the OGLE, GROND, Spitzer, and WISE surveys (Table\u00a01), where black is for the two images of the quasar being unresolved, while the red and blue points are for the resolved images A and B, respectively. Image A (red) is assumed to be a sum of the AGN and its host (at zS\u00a0=\u00a02.16), while image B (blue) due to proximity of the lens galaxy is a sum of the AGN, its host, and the lensing galaxy. In both sub-panels, the solid black line is the best-fitting model, being the sum of the AGN and the host, and a lens galaxy (dashed line): spiral or elliptical. The magenta point is the constraint on the lens magnitude in I band from the PSF fitting. Bottom panel: \u0394\u03c72 as a function of the lens redshift for two types of lensing galaxies and two types of host galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872914/sty259fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872914\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=heTPUAGCcT-mHJvLkkj1zF3kyqI2uz1jvYKz5MEihwGxtufmy2aympe1k~xQfgIYHkggFI9oCaYxDYZJnBLk4gVT-W3h8hFuQUIn8X~T7svFSqwpCRooEvqFVdKU5zyiXCxJ9~rWhHBQtzg2Q5yPNSKXP9ZrzCC0UPPE3nSngZDRMctAJKAdlzdT0XvVFvwhbhgowTZCp1Oxf-JjRsCx3X1rUjgwPfbE5FWosDFCfjDCM-Fzwtwt60sGZSixK-BuyR~TERYJ8R9VzKRXW8S--VgxGZSTHb3iHL0Cco~BA2XFXGBxEq5AfqP384zNdFEZ5tyyIt5t~haURt~WrwQF-A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872914&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SED of the OGLE lens system (top panel) and the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> distribution for the lens redshift (bottom panel). Top panel: the black, red, and blue points come from the OGLE, GROND, <em>Spitzer</em>, and <em>WISE</em> surveys (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), where black is for the two images of the quasar being unresolved, while the red and blue points are for the resolved images A and B, respectively. Image A (red) is assumed to be a sum of the AGN and its host (at <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.16), while image B (blue) due to proximity of the lens galaxy is a sum of the AGN, its host, and the lensing galaxy. In both sub-panels, the solid black line is the best-fitting model, being the sum of the AGN and the host, and a lens galaxy (dashed line): spiral or elliptical. The magenta point is the constraint on the lens magnitude in <em>I</em> band from the PSF fitting. Bottom panel: \u0394\u03c7<sup>2</sup> as a function of the lens redshift for two types of lensing galaxies and two types of host galaxies.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=k-JvgBeUkJk6-KZ7OKIc-JdkgIt8HBof8jnmFNFmqW-gYYnKNk8y9iRDbtinhOW0g5qr6x8~WhSgVE0pV-xcwX4ea56tWO0aqpSvZKj1dOCTqY2KIAMl2Z128wA04Z3wEThYFs~GeCDjC4Fe4v069uu9v2~UttUUIFZ1ju8E5UwlWenm3ZNgGgZYioJPpdomvh6cKjIw8gml~sPEFACkXYSY0sUmVTnoK5mVxIwOFRxrlz1jeVpBHrZP1-EibAOIc23YMeNvhN2phrSg2XheQIXGLF1NjJkvqz28QpVUxW6YiXPXzGYc0mfMrg9tKj19cvfYShprKt2Vrb5lcaKAcw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED of the OGLE lens system (top panel) and the \u03c72 distribution for the lens redshift (bottom panel). Top panel: the black, red, and blue points come from the OGLE, GROND, Spitzer, and WISE surveys (Table\u00a01), where black is for the two images of the quasar being unresolved, while the red and blue points are for the resolved images A and B, respectively. Image A (red) is assumed to be a sum of the AGN and its host (at zS\u00a0=\u00a02.16), while image B (blue) due to proximity of the lens galaxy is a sum of the AGN, its host, and the lensing galaxy. In both sub-panels, the solid black line is the best-fitting model, being the sum of the AGN and the host, and a lens galaxy (dashed line): spiral or elliptical. The magenta point is the constraint on the lens magnitude in I band from the PSF fitting. Bottom panel: \u0394\u03c72 as a function of the lens redshift for two types of lensing galaxies and two types of host galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872914/sty259fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872914\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=heTPUAGCcT-mHJvLkkj1zF3kyqI2uz1jvYKz5MEihwGxtufmy2aympe1k~xQfgIYHkggFI9oCaYxDYZJnBLk4gVT-W3h8hFuQUIn8X~T7svFSqwpCRooEvqFVdKU5zyiXCxJ9~rWhHBQtzg2Q5yPNSKXP9ZrzCC0UPPE3nSngZDRMctAJKAdlzdT0XvVFvwhbhgowTZCp1Oxf-JjRsCx3X1rUjgwPfbE5FWosDFCfjDCM-Fzwtwt60sGZSixK-BuyR~TERYJ8R9VzKRXW8S--VgxGZSTHb3iHL0Cco~BA2XFXGBxEq5AfqP384zNdFEZ5tyyIt5t~haURt~WrwQF-A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872914&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SED of the OGLE lens system (top panel) and the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> distribution for the lens redshift (bottom panel). Top panel: the black, red, and blue points come from the OGLE, GROND, <em>Spitzer</em>, and <em>WISE</em> surveys (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), where black is for the two images of the quasar being unresolved, while the red and blue points are for the resolved images A and B, respectively. Image A (red) is assumed to be a sum of the AGN and its host (at <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.16), while image B (blue) due to proximity of the lens galaxy is a sum of the AGN, its host, and the lensing galaxy. In both sub-panels, the solid black line is the best-fitting model, being the sum of the AGN and the host, and a lens galaxy (dashed line): spiral or elliptical. The magenta point is the constraint on the lens magnitude in <em>I</em> band from the PSF fitting. Bottom panel: \u0394\u03c7<sup>2</sup> as a function of the lens redshift for two types of lensing galaxies and two types of host galaxies.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=112872915 id=\"112872915\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Estimation of the lens redshift</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The estimate of the lens redshift comes from the SED fitting. In order to build an SED, we combined a number of data sets from the literature and observations, totalling 20 bands from ultraviolet (UV) to mid-IR. The near-UV (NUV) data came from Galex (Bianchi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), while both <em>V</em>- and <em>I</em>-band magnitudes were obtained by OGLE-IV (Udalski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We performed dedicated observations of the candidate with GROND (PI: Jochen Greiner) in <em>g</em>\u2033, <em>r</em>\u2033, <em>i</em>\u2033, <em>z</em>\u2033, <em>J, H, K</em> filters (Greiner et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), operated as an imaging instrument at the MPI/ESO 2.2m telescope in La Silla, Chile. The mid-IR data were obtained both from the <em>Spitzer</em> IRAC and MIPS detectors (C1\u2013C4 and C5 channels; the SAGE project; Meixner et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Gordon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and <em>WISE</em> (<em>W</em>1\u2013<em>W</em>4 bands; Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Cutri &amp; et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) space-based telescopes, both covering the 3\u201324 micron range (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). These broad-band magnitudes were converted to luminosities, as prescribed by Koz\u0142owski (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), using the standard \u039bCDM cosmological model.</p>                        <a id=\"112872917\" scrollto-destination=\"112872917\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" (Vega)\u00a0</td><td>7.98\u00a0</td><td>AB\u00a0</td><td>13.24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12\u00a0</td><td>0.64\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>W3</em> (Vega)\u00a0</td><td>22.09\u00a0</td><td>AB\u00a0</td><td>&lt;9.41\u00a0</td><td>&lt;1.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>C5</em> (Vega)\u00a0</td><td>23.68\u00a0</td><td>AB\u00a0</td><td>9.72\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>0.62\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.16\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>NUV</em> (Vega)\u00a0</td><td>22.09\u00a0</td><td>AB\u00a0</td><td>&lt;9.41\u00a0</td><td>&lt;1.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>C5</em> (Vega)\u00a0</td><td>23.68\u00a0</td><td>AB\u00a0</td><td>9.72\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>0.62\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.16\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>C/W stands for <em>Spitzer</em>-IRAC(MIPS)/<em>WISE</em> bands.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The photometry is provided in either AB or Vega systems.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>The magnitudes are extinction corrected.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">*SDSS magnitude system as described in Fukugita et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/112872917\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To fit the SED (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), we used the low-resolution templates of AGN and galaxies from Assef et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We excluded the Galex NUV point from the fitting, because of its unreasonable low value as compared to models. The origin of this discrepancy lies in the fact that the UV flux in distant AGNs is absorbed by neutral hydrogen in the intergalactic medium, a feature that is not taken into account in both the templates used and our simplistic SED modelling. Both the OGLE and GROND data have sufficiently high resolution to measure fluxes for both lensed images, while the <em>Spitzer</em> and <em>WISE</em> data show only a single object due to blending or insufficient resolution. Whenever possible, we fitted the image A (as a sum of the AGN and the host galaxy: either spiral or elliptical) separately from the image B (a sum of the AGN, the host and the lensing galaxy that blends with the image B). We only roughly know the <em>I</em>-band magnitude of the lens galaxy (<em>I</em> \u2248 21.5\u2009mag), that we used as an additional constraint in the SED fitting. We also know the source redshift, so we fixed it in the SED fitting to <em>z<sub>S</sub></em>\u00a0=\u00a02.16. We obtained the lens redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\rm L}=0.94_{-0.28}^{+0.24}$|</span> (90\u2009per\u2009cent CL) for the spiral (insensitive to the AGN host type) and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_{\\rm L}=0.84_{-0.21}^{+0.18}$|</span> (90\u2009per\u2009cent CL) for the elliptical galaxy (also insensitive to the host type). Best-fitting galaxy and AGN models as well as the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> distributions are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We have included the Galactic extinction model as proposed by Cardelli, Clayton &amp; Mathis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>) with <em>R<sub>V</sub></em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1, however, the results turned out to be non-physical and pointing to negative extinctions. Fixing the extinction to positive values provides a slightly lower redshift for the lens galaxy at a price of higher \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. From the SED fit, we can also estimate the lens galaxy stellar mass: (2.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> for the elliptical and (3.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> for the spiral, however, the latter is more than an order of magnitude too high for this type of galaxies (Schawinski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=112872919 id=\"112872919\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Astrometry from OGLE</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Basic properties of the lensing system are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and the finding chart is shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. The lensed system is clearly resolved as two point sources separated by 1.5\u2009arcsec in the OGLE <em>I</em>-band imaging data. The image pixels were modelled to obtain the astrometry of the system. First, we determined the point spread function (PSF) by fitting a nearby star with a parametric Moffat profile. We used four different nearby stars (within\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u2009arcmin) and compared the residuals and the Moffat shape parameters. All the stars are brighter than the quasar images. The brightest star did not give a reasonably good fit consistent with shape parameters for the other stars and it was excluded from the final fit. The Moffat \u03b2 parameter changes between fits but is \u223c2.5. For the final lensed quasar fit, we accounted for the uncertainty in the PSF, hence we allowed the PSF parameters to vary within the measured values (of the other 3 stars) and then marginalize over them. The system was then modelled as a combination of two quasar images (two PSFs) and a galaxy profile, that was set to be a de Vaucouleurs profile convolved with the PSF profile. The free parameters of our model were the 2D positions of the quasar images and lensing galaxy, and the galaxy shape parameters (flattening and effective radius). The model parameters were determined, along with their uncertainties, via sampling with the Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) ensemble sampler \u2013 <span class=\"small-caps\">emcee</span> (Foreman-Mackey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"112872921\" scrollto-destination=\"112872921\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=EiPrnZbdXdRufJuhNOk0ygjhGdsoQjMh43kYarfvfozO1u05qzkiIMyGAwxD5Mj4s-lGWWDgXfYNKVA16ww8PpsbITagDjWiBbRSp9QgJi-~7Ju8NUXmGIVQVJfEuDmQYpdWUYD1vT5LOVhLg-UQdvoSCxkadClZnJV--Foj26ssFdwV1aAUuygxRtivRrQDoaJ5Ptwz8hi1bFuZI9Qu68OyXwSZKyS89bivq4QFRx6fvMJmjo0HkJtwohZPskVM5d8fla3CKqMFUybhiotDy-kHPWTSzXg1rE-qu9Ikxq-PspcifciLTd5R-obuO79S7Dzs-soMyjdkNZdN3Rrhhw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The results of image modelling. The OGLE I-band image is shown (top left-hand panel). It was modelled as a sum of two PSFs and a galaxy. The two lensed quasar images obtained from this model were removed in the top right-hand panel, leaving only the galaxy (marked with the red crosshair in all panels). Residuals after subtracting the best-fitting model including two PSFs is shown only in the bottom left-hand panel. It is clear such a model was insufficient to correctly describe the data. The best model included both the two PSFs and the galaxy, then the residuals became smooth and showed no obvious additional light (bottom right-hand panel). Astrometry and basic parameters of this system are provided in Table\u00a02. All panels cover 8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec2, north is up, east is to the left-hand side.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872921/sty259fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872921\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=E11~e7REq2uWZHQXHX~pOMQVFAYV-kL1oiw7fUjW0FBq97eIkf0GuDICqlZF2YpBVnNQkPSiyZN39oNgTZz-eyI1-j2PE2Wh7ppRCVajDteOHtwWMp06de-87d260-FfwgX1HiUJNKV5Egj3GNZ90-o55U7227xNORfK06G1Pshy5L9VR49~spiYbQzkv~lbpy53soH7isfo3KlOhQbJu00cTOaUlhE-SwmzxX~Cot9h7-ccYGNdAy8sxesPTZ3eizu9ocSZ7I15-4Qz9zZp~eb2ZJyFh2Tn4zgy6SnKaaWcK73TIZysVwp1A5UDJwcjUjchZ-qmF2YIamkNCBBrcg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872921&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of image modelling. The OGLE <em>I</em>-band image is shown (top left-hand panel). It was modelled as a sum of two PSFs and a galaxy. The two lensed quasar images obtained from this model were removed in the top right-hand panel, leaving only the galaxy (marked with the red crosshair in all panels). Residuals after subtracting the best-fitting model including two PSFs is shown only in the bottom left-hand panel. It is clear such a model was insufficient to correctly describe the data. The best model included both the two PSFs and the galaxy, then the residuals became smooth and showed no obvious additional light (bottom right-hand panel). Astrometry and basic parameters of this system are provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. All panels cover 8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup>, north is up, east is to the left-hand side.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=EiPrnZbdXdRufJuhNOk0ygjhGdsoQjMh43kYarfvfozO1u05qzkiIMyGAwxD5Mj4s-lGWWDgXfYNKVA16ww8PpsbITagDjWiBbRSp9QgJi-~7Ju8NUXmGIVQVJfEuDmQYpdWUYD1vT5LOVhLg-UQdvoSCxkadClZnJV--Foj26ssFdwV1aAUuygxRtivRrQDoaJ5Ptwz8hi1bFuZI9Qu68OyXwSZKyS89bivq4QFRx6fvMJmjo0HkJtwohZPskVM5d8fla3CKqMFUybhiotDy-kHPWTSzXg1rE-qu9Ikxq-PspcifciLTd5R-obuO79S7Dzs-soMyjdkNZdN3Rrhhw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The results of image modelling. The OGLE I-band image is shown (top left-hand panel). It was modelled as a sum of two PSFs and a galaxy. The two lensed quasar images obtained from this model were removed in the top right-hand panel, leaving only the galaxy (marked with the red crosshair in all panels). Residuals after subtracting the best-fitting model including two PSFs is shown only in the bottom left-hand panel. It is clear such a model was insufficient to correctly describe the data. The best model included both the two PSFs and the galaxy, then the residuals became smooth and showed no obvious additional light (bottom right-hand panel). Astrometry and basic parameters of this system are provided in Table\u00a02. All panels cover 8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec2, north is up, east is to the left-hand side.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872921/sty259fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872921\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=E11~e7REq2uWZHQXHX~pOMQVFAYV-kL1oiw7fUjW0FBq97eIkf0GuDICqlZF2YpBVnNQkPSiyZN39oNgTZz-eyI1-j2PE2Wh7ppRCVajDteOHtwWMp06de-87d260-FfwgX1HiUJNKV5Egj3GNZ90-o55U7227xNORfK06G1Pshy5L9VR49~spiYbQzkv~lbpy53soH7isfo3KlOhQbJu00cTOaUlhE-SwmzxX~Cot9h7-ccYGNdAy8sxesPTZ3eizu9ocSZ7I15-4Qz9zZp~eb2ZJyFh2Tn4zgy6SnKaaWcK73TIZysVwp1A5UDJwcjUjchZ-qmF2YIamkNCBBrcg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872921&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of image modelling. The OGLE <em>I</em>-band image is shown (top left-hand panel). It was modelled as a sum of two PSFs and a galaxy. The two lensed quasar images obtained from this model were removed in the top right-hand panel, leaving only the galaxy (marked with the red crosshair in all panels). Residuals after subtracting the best-fitting model including two PSFs is shown only in the bottom left-hand panel. It is clear such a model was insufficient to correctly describe the data. The best model included both the two PSFs and the galaxy, then the residuals became smooth and showed no obvious additional light (bottom right-hand panel). Astrometry and basic parameters of this system are provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. All panels cover 8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup>, north is up, east is to the left-hand side.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"112872922\"
