(mag)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<sub><em>I</em></sub> (mag)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(\u2009arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(counts)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>5377.90992\u00a0</td><td>19.801\u00a0</td><td>0.156\u00a0</td><td>19.708\u00a0</td><td>0.143\u00a0</td><td>1.528\u00a0</td><td>1.55\u00a0</td><td>696\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5386.92763\u00a0</td><td>19.898\u00a0</td><td>0.080\u00a0</td><td>19.870\u00a0</td><td>0.080\u00a0</td><td>1.450\u00a0</td><td>1.12\u00a0</td><td>253\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5388.92893\u00a0</td><td>19.846\u00a0</td><td>0.087\u00a0</td><td>19.942\u00a0</td><td>0.097\u00a0</td><td>1.441\u00a0</td><td>1.24\u00a0</td><td>245\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5389.93796\u00a0</td><td>20.010\u00a0</td><td>0.125\u00a0</td><td>19.974\u00a0</td><td>0.122\u00a0</td><td>1.428\u00a0</td><td>1.61\u00a0</td><td>336\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5392.92310\u00a0</td><td>19.975\u00a0</td><td>0.154\u00a0</td><td>19.875\u00a0</td><td>0.140\u00a0</td><td>1.435\u00a0</td><td>2.01\u00a0</td><td>320\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>HJD-2450000<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image A<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image A<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image B<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image B<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Airmass<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Background<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>(days)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>I</em> (mag)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<sub><em>I</em></sub> (mag)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>I</em> (mag)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<sub><em>I</em></sub> (mag)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(\u2009arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(counts)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>5377.90992\u00a0</td><td>19.801\u00a0</td><td>0.156\u00a0</td><td>19.708\u00a0</td><td>0.143\u00a0</td><td>1.528\u00a0</td><td>1.55\u00a0</td><td>696\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5386.92763\u00a0</td><td>19.898\u00a0</td><td>0.080\u00a0</td><td>19.870\u00a0</td><td>0.080\u00a0</td><td>1.450\u00a0</td><td>1.12\u00a0</td><td>253\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5388.92893\u00a0</td><td>19.846\u00a0</td><td>0.087\u00a0</td><td>19.942\u00a0</td><td>0.097\u00a0</td><td>1.441\u00a0</td><td>1.24\u00a0</td><td>245\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5389.93796\u00a0</td><td>20.010\u00a0</td><td>0.125\u00a0</td><td>19.974\u00a0</td><td>0.122\u00a0</td><td>1.428\u00a0</td><td>1.61\u00a0</td><td>336\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5392.92310\u00a0</td><td>19.975\u00a0</td><td>0.154\u00a0</td><td>19.875\u00a0</td><td>0.140\u00a0</td><td>1.435\u00a0</td><td>2.01\u00a0</td><td>320\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/112872926\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">From the OGLE photometry of template images (now in the standard Johnson\u2013Cousins Vega system), we find that the colours of the lensed images are (<em>V</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>I</em>)<sub>A</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.48\u2009mag and (<em>V</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>I</em>)<sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.78\u2009mag, so the image B is redder than A, what is also readily visible in the top right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. This may point to two scenarios: (1) image B is a composite of the lensing galaxy and the lensed quasar, or (2) image B is redder due to extinction in the lensed galaxy. If scenario (1) is the case, then we can easily estimate the <em>I</em>-band magnitudes of the two sources (assuming the <em>V</em>-band lens galaxy flux is negligible). The lensing galaxy brightness is <em>I</em>\u00a0=\u00a021.23\u2009mag and the lensed image has the brightness of <em>I</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a020.02\u2009mag (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). The lensing galaxy <em>I</em>-band brightness is confirmed by the measurement obtained from the PSF fitting. On the other hand, from the SED modelling, we find the \u2018pure\u2019 flux ratio between images A (61\u2009per\u2009cent of light of the total AB light) and B (39\u2009per\u2009cent) is \u223c1.6 with the formal uncertainty of 0.1, therefore the magnitude difference between images is \u223c0.5\u2009mag, however, the lensing galaxy contributes significantly to the flux of image B due to its proximity. In the near-IR, the flux ratio decreases to below 1.0, where the image B appears to be brighter than A, but in fact the best SED model of the lensing galaxy peaks around 2\u2009\u03bcm and dominates the light of image B (bottom panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and top panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=112872928 id=\"112872928\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-5>3.5 The time delay</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Time delays in gravitational lenses may be the key to understanding the lens system, including its mass distribution, but also are probes of cosmological parameters such as the Hubble constant (e.g. Blandford &amp; Narayan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>; Gorenstein, Shapiro &amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Time delay(s) are estimated from light curves of the two (or more) images of the quasar. The necessary condition is that all light curves cover the same variability pattern intrinsic to the quasar. This usually means a need for about several years-long, well-sampled light curves having a good signal-to-noise (i.e. sufficiently bright images), because the typical AGN variability amplitude is small, a few tenths of a magnitude, on a time-scale of months to years (e.g. MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Koz\u0142owski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). If the separation between the image(s) and the galaxy is small, or simply the galaxy is large (as in the case of QSO 2237+0305; e.g. Huchra et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1985</a>; Udalski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), then one or more images may undergo secondary microlensing by stars of the lensing galaxy. This happens rather frequently and is the main reason of troubles with correctly estimating time delays (e.g. Goicoechea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Tie &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and the image flux ratios (e.g. Wyithe &amp; Turner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), while on the other hand enabling the measurement of the intrinsic properties of the quasar accretion disc (its temperature profile and size, e.g. Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Dai et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Mosquera et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A straightforward method to measure time delay(s) is the cross-correlation (CC) of the two (or more) light curves, however because the data points are rarely regularly sampled, one needs to interpolate (or sometimes extrapolate) one of the light curves to match the points of the first light curve. The exact choice of inter/extrapolating/modelling method is tricky \u2013 one can simply use the spline/straight line or similar method of interpolation or one can try to model the quasar variability as the damped random walk (DRW; e.g. Kelly, Bechtold &amp; Siemiginowska <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Koz\u0142owski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) or even more sophisticated continuous-time autoregressive moving average (CARMA; e.g. Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) models and then simultaneously search for the time delays.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, to increase the signal-to-noise ratio in the light curves, we combine the data into 10-d contiguous bins, and then whenever necessary interpolate such light curves using DRW model (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). From a structure function analysis, we know that the asymptotic variability is SF<sub>\u221e</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.30\u2009mag and that the structure function power-law slope is \u03b3 \u2248 0.5, as required by DRW model. The DRW time-scale was fixed to 1\u2009yr rest-frame (Koz\u0142owski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). We cross-correlated such a DRW-interpolated light curve to obtain a weakly constrained time delay of <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub> \u2248 \u221283 \u2009d and allowing for a wide range of negative values (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), where the image A leads the image B what is in line with expectations from the geometry as image A is farther from the galaxy and it should always lead.</p>                        <a id=\"112872933\" scrollto-destination=\"112872933\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=ZVToigqwLL9yMpUZ-YrMU-CxkaypkVvCT7yIpfXpAS1RWKpceGBKZTNco8ypPuftMOwLO5rElh5BeKXUVew6lUa6rtF2HoDS9liGH3GI3FLD55I8Jt4iVg~8fHWv~YoxIXpw3Vt46pFOdOpM7wWAi6Ym0GyvZ15zUZErK2p8QI0emrfifHHEKKOe9Isty5olvoOmWuKnnHZofnwDMTNcM--ECv1mgLc4ArRU8D3ox~sR9A0nkFpBKhCn2inKZzJl7xC5LDdlYknJc8Mku454VzMvdk087HIcYhiNrmPzdISVdSHKoCPOjHjnDyeh5XO6Ikhv33K0ghleT1DGBIAt7Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top panels: 10-d binned light curves of the two images A (red) and B (blue) of the lensed quasar. The upper panel shows the data as observed, while the bottom one is for image B shifted by \u2212102\u2009d (see Section\u00a03.5). Bottom panels: We present the DRW models for both images, where the data are interpolated and extrapolated to within 10\u2009d of each original data point. Similarly to the upper panels, we show the best model light curves as observed (top panel) and with the image B shifted by \u2212102\u2009d (bottom panel).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872933/sty259fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872933\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=DysS85BiCYYgWe6kpZ5IjCleQcYD7lfc~HQ8msII2cur9sHTrMwlp8iJym5vFcO9v1AtHRJtCpbahpU5okN0e9DG2Hk5Ed-Ln6nrpFv4~o01vDf~06plle4kGYrM17jW2CUtUNKxD~g6aiY15X5vRRQMLCeM0H~-vy4IRc8BsNybSpuXPiW8WQu~aR3MrB9J48g3QAHz0gf~iSLyj82Deq~bMF934VuxO7KwiXsYh5zv4SX5OJoHVZw-bs~ax1yNoUxRkMnSqPjE05r5~uIqGICIhYw3dr-xBUgXPTKBePMFVN10aPWVMfnWWPiS3VjvEE5t3xvEYL3CAIuZpS8SIA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872933&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top panels: 10-d binned light curves of the two images A (red) and B (blue) of the lensed quasar. The upper panel shows the data as observed, while the bottom one is for image B shifted by \u2212102\u2009d (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.5</a>). The cleaned light curves have the 90\u2009per\u2009cent time delay limits spanning \u2212151\u00a0&lt;\u00a0tAB\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221275 \u2009d with the median of tAB\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212108 \u2009d, while the binned light curves have \u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0tAB\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221276 \u2009d and tAB\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212102 \u2009d, respectively. The cleaned light curves have the 90\u2009per\u2009cent time delay limits spanning \u2212151\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221275 \u2009d with the median of <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212108 \u2009d, while the binned light curves have \u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221276 \u2009d and <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212102 \u2009d, respectively. The blue line is the resulting time delay distribution from our <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> code, that returned the median time delay of <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221290 \u2009d, where the 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence limits are \u2212119\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221257 \u2009d. In green (right <em>y</em>-axis), we show the CC of the 10-d binned data interpolated with DRW model, that broadly peaks at <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221283 \u2009d.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=QsUnN2MUrpTxl6DUzFapfwHVt7Ya0rfxo6H4v1-AJ-6oOvDfD2SK5bueTCzfh2pwRe8uegtTbO5RLtKZ9zSKI-h-B3fs94hc6oBEHL-ZzoCkUAagy5kwEyvhBlj4mNrfHqwh1F1dRUEhxBNnIFUxNfhD3EDscr9HQ1RiXtF4FFbT0SBccmmxhhhDR21TIWceu-7H95SBvJ~HO8b8mp1UlbFPJZaz3UtJxwprq0j6Ziv7QBQRJL-fnjUGWePTxYwYr6Gv0PQMkiKQ9VwcmkgcP87Bxb8UJ-CQ7hJgoLYpSDAZn~WE5~DzMHXUg1EEwRNxigeK41dDN4HJjKu3ItpLkQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The observed-frame time delay density probability obtained using Javelin on the cleaned (black) and 10-d binned (red) OGLE light curves is shown. The cleaned light curves have the 90\u2009per\u2009cent time delay limits spanning \u2212151\u00a0&lt;\u00a0tAB\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221275 \u2009d with the median of tAB\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212108 \u2009d, while the binned light curves have \u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0tAB\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221276 \u2009d and tAB\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212102 \u2009d, respectively. In green (right y-axis), we show the CC of the 10-d binned data interpolated with DRW model, that broadly peaks at tAB\u00a0=\u00a0\u221283 \u2009d.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872934/sty259fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872934\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=gdeO7Haros6QEM96j9RunXwA~RxYInv5XMq1KEHHfT56E7XJP5SRmPJw~9-Lou9KwYZZTgAYTLhGMiBoP7qCqDjw6vtisOkIJsDDt~w8FRxLeexYfbkNrBSHnGedfToz93TRvqS8Ns-~P5Xtzn21vw5u71DiIUiDxkuVO1uaa9Icyu7NyBehIeeoKp8m2VqDRTJlE-GFqMi8CO39qQ~6B7OGwg3VUq8s~SJGkVYHCjlyxbzWzYVM1B5i5v4Emq9ksfkkRiZ~O9id5cpxlfyMeqMitW2R1ulv5M2dHi304l26SLCOtdBIlXMhaf8ftmfibFFY1AZ6sZ76xYsgwQjbMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872934&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed-frame time delay density probability obtained using J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span> on the cleaned (black) and 10-d binned (red) OGLE light curves is shown. The cleaned light curves have the 90\u2009per\u2009cent time delay limits spanning \u2212151\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221275 \u2009d with the median of <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212108 \u2009d, while the binned light curves have \u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221276 \u2009d and <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212102 \u2009d, respectively. The blue line is the resulting time delay distribution from our <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> code, that returned the median time delay of <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221290 \u2009d, where the 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence limits are \u2212119\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221257 \u2009d. In green (right <em>y</em>-axis), we show the CC of the 10-d binned data interpolated with DRW model, that broadly peaks at <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221283 \u2009d.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>) provide a method of estimating the time delay between the images of the quasar, where the intrinsic variations of the source can be approximated as a Legendre series of order N<sub>src</sub> and are present in all images shifted by the time delay, while the secondary variations due to microlensing are approximated by another Legendre series of order N<sub>\u03bc</sub>. The orders of both series are typically set by using the F-test. In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, we present the results for three low-order variability polynomials N<sub>src</sub>\u00a0=\u00a010, 20, and 30, and the lowest order microlensing polynomial with N<sub>\u03bc</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01. The time delays are typically within the 1\u03c3 range of \u2212100\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221270\u2009\u2009d.</p>                        <a id=\"112872936\" scrollto-destination=\"112872936\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Time delays obtained using the Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>) method (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.5</a> for explanations).</p></div> </div><div .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>best\u00a0</td><td><em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221289 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212106\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221272 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212124\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221256 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>3\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212142\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221241 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof\u00a0</td><td>222.6/219\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>best\u00a0</td><td><em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221284 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u221297\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221272 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212111\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221260 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>3\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212126\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221248 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof\u00a0</td><td>185.6/209\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>best\u00a0</td><td><em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221284 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u221299\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221271 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212116\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221249 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>3\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221232 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof\u00a0</td><td>167.1/199\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><em>N</em><sub>src</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>\u03bc</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Parameter<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Value<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>best\u00a0</td><td><em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221289 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof\u00a0</td><td>222.6/219\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>best\u00a0</td><td><em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221284 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u221297\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221272 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212111\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221260 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof\u00a0</td><td>185.6/209\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>best\u00a0</td><td><em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221284 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u221299\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221271 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212116\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221249   \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/112872936\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Time delays obtained using the Kochanek et\u00a0al. class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><em>N</em><sub>src</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>\u03bc</sub><span .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>best\u00a0</td><td><em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221289 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212106\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221272 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212124\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221256 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>3\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212142\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221241 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof\u00a0</td><td>222.6/219\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>best\u00a0</td><td><em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221284 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u221297\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221272 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212111\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221260 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>3\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212126\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221248 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof\u00a0</td><td>185.6/209\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>best\u00a0</td><td><em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221284 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u221299\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221271 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212116\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221249 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>3\u03c3\u00a0</td><td>\u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221232 \u2009d\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>30\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof\u00a0</td><td>167.1/199\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/112872936\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span> software is designed to search for time delays between two or more time series, where the time series is intrinsically modelled as the DRW model (Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Koz\u0142owski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). However, it does not simultaneously model any additional variability in each light curves due to microlensing. We used J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span> to search for time delays for both full (but cleaned of bad points) and 10-d binned light curves. The time delay density probability distributions are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The median time delays are <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212108 \u2009d and <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212102 \u2009d, respectively, while the 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence limits are \u2212151\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221275 \u2009d and \u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221276 \u2009d. As a cross-check, we also used our own <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> DRW-modelling time-delay searching code. The results are comparable, although the time delay is a little shorter, with the median <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u221290 \u2009d and the 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence limits of \u2212119\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221257 \u2009d.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The CC, the Kochanek method, and the <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> code seem to prefer slightly shorter, but not disjoint, time delays to the ones derived from the J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span> code. For further discussions, throughout this paper we will adopt the following median time delay of <em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212102 \u2009d and the 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence level of \u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221276 \u2009d, which are the results from the J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span> modelling of the 10-d binned data.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=112872939 id=\"112872939\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=112872940 id=\"112872940\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Modelling the lensing system</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The available data and their uncertainties limit our ability to fully model the lensing system. As an approximation, we modelled the lens by adopting the singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) model for the lens mass density profile (Kormann, Schneider &amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>), and using the <span class=\"small-caps\">gravlens</span> software (Keeton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). We obtained the Einstein radius of <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.78\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01\u2009arcsec, axis ratio 0.91\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05, and position angle 90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020 (in degrees measured east of north) from exploring the parameter space with MCMC sampling. The basic SIE model leads to the discrepancy in fitted values of axis ratio between mass and light profile but one has to remember that the external shear was not taken into account and/or the SIE model may be too simplistic. For the measured time delays, the <span class=\"small-caps\">gravlens</span> modelling results point to the lens redshift (used here as a free parameter and so sampled for) and the lens mass. The lens redshift is found to be 0.83\u20131.12 (90\u2009per\u2009cent CL) and the lens mass within the Einstein radius 4\u20136\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). The estimated lens redshift from the SED modelling is in excellent agreement with our prediction from the lens model; however, the uncertainties are large.</p>                        <a id=\"112872942\" scrollto-destination=\"112872942\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=mw-5P7r~89nF0-tckcFy7gwiL5Dl5N51hSx4jJzmdDrjUA3pLmYAEDC-KGg0M2rmrKSqW~Q6kxOJWJOaypHOLftB4GAq9H9~tyzZXTPbjsTmr9SmTTwaJnaosm7qtsdod71T4bhR3auMRn9hnrt7ERmKx45oPEBfwKOKBKRgZrt-w6EKRybYzB01QgFVmMpyWJpaBmqNLOk0LOJO-xzKIo3rnka83gCRzFsuUdAsu7CsPTkyhHxsbOo9GbgC-3WePMS826gaf6snavgUtvdr51NvBlGjU2v3qDCJOyR7perV4TsYivNQzff0YVY6eAOpqjWGndW6WjMAQ6EnrvwIiA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The time delay (left-hand panel y-axis) and the approximate lens mass (right-hand panel y-axis) as a function of redshift. The inclined line shows the prediction based on the simple SIE lens model. The horizontal blue line indicates the time delay of |tAB|\u00a0=\u00a0102 \u2009d, while the light blue region represents 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels. The two vertical lines mark the best-fitted SED redshifts for the spiral (left-hand panel; zL\u00a0=\u00a00.94) and elliptical galaxy (right-hand panel; zL\u00a0=\u00a00.84), when the source redshift is fixed to the spectroscopically measured value (zS\u00a0=\u00a02.16) in the SED fitting. The green areas mark the 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels for these redshifts, while in red, we mark the overlapping 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels for both the time delay and redshifts. The best estimate for the lens galaxy mass is \u223c5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01011\u2009M\u2299 within the Einstein radius.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872942/sty259fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872942\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=aospX6QrYPJ2Q1B0xX7n8kywt0jrqeAKHJecJYJPIMhmeqNUq00tn7Iy5lM8jclqFr9sCBc4WhMGhLBKflw4yre9oMC1zZfn4-avLdhkJCfm3ohc0XjX1-weWc9gLOHT9mByuyIMk~ZSgrzL3DzXIlyA3WcJjMKxJeh~TMlqXplI~VFi8fvY6gu0g6rNPYgMFSGc5B38uA9adElRBbPXt1DEwOAIch1c9hPFfrTSz0VAvQJ0gWsLSu6rDoCiHU08BFVntIU-u-7COhRn9HKpvpyQS6hCV1XGtaFHlu7m8Th4lKjVNENFpyxcXZNyc975y495s0KhPkCbAhUqZYJq1Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872942&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The time delay (left-hand panel <em>y</em>-axis) and the approximate lens mass (right-hand panel <em>y</em>-axis) as a function of redshift. The inclined line shows the prediction based on the simple SIE lens model. The horizontal blue line indicates the time delay of |<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>|\u00a0=\u00a0102 \u2009d, while the light blue region represents 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels. The two vertical lines mark the best-fitted SED redshifts for the spiral (left-hand panel; <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.94) and elliptical galaxy (right-hand panel; <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.84), when the source redshift is fixed to the spectroscopically measured value (<em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.16) in the SED fitting. The green areas mark the 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels for these redshifts, while in red, we mark the overlapping 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels for both the time delay and redshifts. The best estimate for the lens galaxy mass is \u223c5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> within the Einstein radius.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=mw-5P7r~89nF0-tckcFy7gwiL5Dl5N51hSx4jJzmdDrjUA3pLmYAEDC-KGg0M2rmrKSqW~Q6kxOJWJOaypHOLftB4GAq9H9~tyzZXTPbjsTmr9SmTTwaJnaosm7qtsdod71T4bhR3auMRn9hnrt7ERmKx45oPEBfwKOKBKRgZrt-w6EKRybYzB01QgFVmMpyWJpaBmqNLOk0LOJO-xzKIo3rnka83gCRzFsuUdAsu7CsPTkyhHxsbOo9GbgC-3WePMS826gaf6snavgUtvdr51NvBlGjU2v3qDCJOyR7perV4TsYivNQzff0YVY6eAOpqjWGndW6WjMAQ6EnrvwIiA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The time delay (left-hand panel y-axis) and the approximate lens mass (right-hand panel y-axis) as a function of redshift. The inclined line shows the prediction based on the simple SIE lens model. The horizontal blue line indicates the time delay of |tAB|\u00a0=\u00a0102 \u2009d, while the light blue region represents 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels. The two vertical lines mark the best-fitted SED redshifts for the spiral (left-hand panel; zL\u00a0=\u00a00.94) and elliptical galaxy (right-hand panel; zL\u00a0=\u00a00.84), when the source redshift is fixed to the spectroscopically measured value (zS\u00a0=\u00a02.16) in the SED fitting. The green areas mark the 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels for these redshifts, while in red, we mark the overlapping 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels for both the time delay and redshifts. The best estimate for the lens galaxy mass is \u223c5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01011\u2009M\u2299 within the Einstein radius.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872942/sty259fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872942\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=aospX6QrYPJ2Q1B0xX7n8kywt0jrqeAKHJecJYJPIMhmeqNUq00tn7Iy5lM8jclqFr9sCBc4WhMGhLBKflw4yre9oMC1zZfn4-avLdhkJCfm3ohc0XjX1-weWc9gLOHT9mByuyIMk~ZSgrzL3DzXIlyA3WcJjMKxJeh~TMlqXplI~VFi8fvY6gu0g6rNPYgMFSGc5B38uA9adElRBbPXt1DEwOAIch1c9hPFfrTSz0VAvQJ0gWsLSu6rDoCiHU08BFVntIU-u-7COhRn9HKpvpyQS6hCV1XGtaFHlu7m8Th4lKjVNENFpyxcXZNyc975y495s0KhPkCbAhUqZYJq1Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872942&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The time delay (left-hand panel <em>y</em>-axis) and the approximate lens mass (right-hand panel <em>y</em>-axis) as a function of redshift. The inclined line shows the prediction based on the simple SIE lens model. The horizontal blue line indicates the time delay of |<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>|\u00a0=\u00a0102 \u2009d, while the light blue region represents 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels. The two vertical lines mark the best-fitted SED redshifts for the spiral (left-hand panel; <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.94) and elliptical galaxy (right-hand panel; <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.84), when the source redshift is fixed to the spectroscopically measured value (<em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.16) in the SED fitting. The green areas mark the 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels for these redshifts, while in red, we mark the overlapping 90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence levels for both the time delay and redshifts. The best estimate for the lens galaxy mass is \u223c5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> within the Einstein radius.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The best-estimated total lens galaxy mass implies a stellar mass of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> assuming a typical stellar-to-total mass ratio within the Einstein radius of \u223c0.5 (e.g. Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). This number can be compared against the galaxy mass distributions for late-type (spiral and irregular) and early-type (elliptical and lenticular) galaxies from SDSS. Our derived mass is by far more likely found in elliptical galaxies than in spirals (Schawinski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Another confirmation comes from the SED modelling, where we estimate the stellar mass for the lens being elliptical or spiral galaxy with (2.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> and (3.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>, respectively. Both values broadly agree with the expectation from the lens model.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=112872944 id=\"112872944\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Detectability of lenses in OGLE</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">According to predictions presented by Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), there should be 1 gravitational lens for <em>I</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a019\u2009mag, 3 lenses for <em>I</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a020\u2009mag, 8 lenses for <em>I</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a021\u2009mag, and 20 lenses (both doubles and quads) for <em>I</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a021.5\u2009mag (the detection limit in OGLE) within the area of about 670deg<sup>2</sup> around the Magellanic Clouds. We adopted the typical quasar colour of (<em>i</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>I</em>) \u2248 0.4\u2009mag (fig. 9 in Koz\u0142owski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) to convert the Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) <em>i</em>-band magnitudes into <em>I</em> band. Our candidate selection was partly based, however, on a requirement of detecting quasar variability. Koz\u0142owski (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) showed that the rms of the optical variability of quasars reaches about 0.25\u2009mag, provided the light curves are sufficiently long. The rms of the photometric noise in OGLE-IV is 0.06\u2009mag for <em>I</em>\u00a0=\u00a019\u2009mag, 0.13\u2009mag for <em>I</em>\u00a0=\u00a020\u2009mag, and 0.30\u2009mag for objects with <em>I</em>\u00a0=\u00a021\u2009mag (Udalski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). So the expected number of found lensing systems will be actually lower due to the fact that only a fraction of quasars is sufficiently variable around <em>I</em> \u2248 20\u2009mag to exceed the photometric noise in OGLE. Ignoring other factors, such as the high stellar crowding, we should, in principle, detect fewer than five gravitational lenses. This number still could be lower in our case, because a fraction of the analysed area has been observed only for three years at the time of this search, so a fraction of quasars show lower rms variability. This implies that our detection efficiency is at least 20\u2009per\u2009cent (&gt;1/5).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=112872946 id=\"112872946\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We presented the results from our search for lensed quasars in the OGLE Variability Survey's data in the extended area of the Magellanic Clouds. Our first candidate, that we confirmed spectroscopically, is a lensed quasar at a redshift of <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.16, with two quasar images separated by 1.5\u2009arcsec on the sky. After subtracting the two lensed images from a deep OGLE frame, we detected the lensing galaxy with <em>I</em> \u2248 21.5\u2009mag. From the SED modelling spanning 0.2\u201324 microns and having the fixed source redshift, we found that the lensing galaxy could be both a spiral or an elliptical at the redshift of <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> \u2248 0.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2, although an elliptical galaxy is preferred. This redshift is also expected from the simplest SIE lens model with the measured time delay of \u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221276\u2009d (90\u2009per\u2009cent CL).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If the lens was a spiral this would raise a potential question on the amount of the expected extinction to be present in the SED of the quasar images (but undetected), because the lines of sight pass approximately 8\u2009kpc (for image A) and 3\u2009kpc (for B) from the galaxy lens centre. For a very massive spiral with the stellar mass of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>, this would likely mean passing through the spiral arms containing dust (unless it is edge on and has a favourable position angle, the latter being the case here as the PA is roughly perpendicular to the line joining the images). However, the lensing mass is nearly circular, which is inconsistent with an edge-on disc. Furthermore, our derived stellar mass is typically seen in elliptical galaxies and is generally too high, by roughly an order of magnitude, for spirals (Schawinski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To obtain the time delay of \u2212132\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u221276\u2009d (90\u2009per\u2009cent CL), we used several available methods that included the DRW light curve modelling with J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span>, but also with our own <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> code, the Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006b</a>) method using the Legendre polynomials, and also CC. All these methods provided consistent results, although the J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span> software preferred slightly longer time delays.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We proposed another detection route of gravitationally lensed systems, first through the \u2018red\u2019 mid-IR <em>WISE</em> colours, typical for quasars, and then including the identification of point source pairs in optical data showing similar variability patterns. Our search method does not require any prior spectroscopic observations.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=112872951 id=\"112872951\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We are grateful to the anonymous referee for providing us with comments that improved this manuscript. ZKR acknowledges support from European Research Council Consolidator Grant 647208. SK acknowledges the financial support of the Polish National Science Centre through the OPUS grant number 2014/15/B/ST9/00093. TA and YA acknowledge support by proyecto FONDECYT 11130630 and by the Ministry for the Economy, Development, and Tourism's Programa Inicativa Cient\u00edfica Milenio through grant IC 12009, awarded to The Millennium Institute of Astrophysics (MAS). OGLE project has received funding from the Polish National Science Centre, grant MAESTRO 2014/14/A/ST9/00121 to AU. Part of the funding for GROND (both hardware as well as personnel) was generously granted from the Leibniz-Prize to Prof. G. Hasinger (DFG grant HA 1850/28-1).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This publication makes use of data products from the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer, which is a joint project of the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.</p>                    <h2 S.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Koz\u0142owski</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">S.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Peterson</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">B. M.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2016</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">819</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">122</div><div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.3847/0004-637X/819/2/122\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.3847/0004-637X/819/2/122</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.3847/0004-637X/819/2/122\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.3847%2F0004-637X%2F819%2F2%2F122\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.3847%2F0004-637X%2F819%2F2%2F122\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=112872957 id=\"112872957\" class=\"backsection-title\" >SUPPORTING INFORMATION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Supplementary data are available at <em><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/mnras/sty259#supplementary-data\" target=\"_blank\">MNRAS</a></em> online.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>Table3_online.txt</strong></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Please note: Oxford University Press is not responsible for the content or functionality of any supporting materials supplied by the authors. Any queries (other than missing material) should be directed to the corresponding author for the article.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=112872962 id=\"112872962\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>APPENDIX A: OTHER OBSERVED CANDIDATES</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we present basic information on the two spectroscopically observed lensed quasar candidates, which turned out to be unlensed quasar+star pairs. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>, we present the finding charts, the NTT spectra and the OGLE light curves in <em>I</em> band. Both candidates were observed on 2016 December 5 with the EFOSC2. Both quasars show common AGN broad emission lines at the redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.465 and 1.49. The spectra of nearby interlopers are also presented for comparison.</p>                        <a id=\"112872964\" scrollto-destination=\"112872964\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=eyd~jfZSITkD8NDkBiXo0Y45u81KqTvUyjRvO3PmQk3ImeO4RK142XwgenHcwpkMi-Ik0dq13gxCTxgxLmY15ppWmmQ8FeYIJwT2~RT0etvb2owGQV5wVPxCaaMYXbN-2ms353JDyZsyIscAIWKPmQI-P0yJiSOtY4HGTjU8-TIBTlbAQf1k7Jff2QPoE-e0konlgduJL9JxyoT27xU3LxeOlI1GBtpcvptzQRPtObVGfQPETSmXedPnle9H8V179bJx3z0nW22hVq~YlXZ1b7oJTfbA-6PZar8HK3i0j-tLdxWIll~VusAQFh0naDxYO-XLZtsgC2ZZbRB4tcAptg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Two spectroscopically observed candidates that turned out to be regular quasars with a nearby interloper. In the left-hand panel, we present 1 by 1\u2009arcmin finding charts centred at these sources, in the middle panels, we show the NTT spectra with the main quasar emission lines marked as vertical lines, and in the right-hand panels, we present the OGLE-IV light curves. The best estimate Javelin time delays are \u22122\u2009d (top) and 15\u2009d (bottom).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259figa1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872964/sty259figa1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259figa1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872964\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=fSdGT-DR31uALWCndrltWwV7Svp6dUml1OdZk4SOaKhvq-7j~YfBqE3cyDJ3ny7boEvzG-h5AUUw2GmqNqWmRSgx72xm4MkcMuXpn6vIw7tLa-NG~W~EDadDw-UswYtb6ENkT~j~i-9hpLkwQkzaUdGIZqhJ5oYOwGmm-dmQ2xGnu9EoJPCI5-rcRN6XFsZS1uTRDD9BA63e1GvWCovEfhdHac1JwAAL~KwrkWCycHNeTU2Utm9srpUjGt17qQ1YdZxTeDzpByGUVDbEAkQxFPmrTllGCuWMJpLnPGBRsafpG7-0rE04bRmz2DtqCzk0YeECi1tQgC4hOxzOoG8t4g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872964&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259figa1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two spectroscopically observed candidates that turned out to be regular quasars with a nearby interloper. In the left-hand panel, we present 1 by 1\u2009arcmin finding charts centred at these sources, in the middle panels, we show the NTT spectra with the main quasar emission lines marked as vertical lines, and in the right-hand panels, we present the OGLE-IV light curves. The best estimate J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span> time delays are \u22122\u2009d (top) and 15\u2009d (bottom).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/m_sty259figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&amp;Signature=eyd~jfZSITkD8NDkBiXo0Y45u81KqTvUyjRvO3PmQk3ImeO4RK142XwgenHcwpkMi-Ik0dq13gxCTxgxLmY15ppWmmQ8FeYIJwT2~RT0etvb2owGQV5wVPxCaaMYXbN-2ms353JDyZsyIscAIWKPmQI-P0yJiSOtY4HGTjU8-TIBTlbAQf1k7Jff2QPoE-e0konlgduJL9JxyoT27xU3LxeOlI1GBtpcvptzQRPtObVGfQPETSmXedPnle9H8V179bJx3z0nW22hVq~YlXZ1b7oJTfbA-6PZar8HK3i0j-tLdxWIll~VusAQFh0naDxYO-XLZtsgC2ZZbRB4tcAptg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Two spectroscopically observed candidates that turned out to be regular quasars with a nearby interloper. The best estimate Javelin time delays are \u22122\u2009d (top) and 15\u2009d (bottom).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259figa1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/112872964/sty259figa1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259figa1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"112872964\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611466179&Signature=fSdGT-DR31uALWCndrltWwV7Svp6dUml1OdZk4SOaKhvq-7j~YfBqE3cyDJ3ny7boEvzG-h5AUUw2GmqNqWmRSgx72xm4MkcMuXpn6vIw7tLa-NG~W~EDadDw-UswYtb6ENkT~j~i-9hpLkwQkzaUdGIZqhJ5oYOwGmm-dmQ2xGnu9EoJPCI5-rcRN6XFsZS1uTRDD9BA63e1GvWCovEfhdHac1JwAAL~KwrkWCycHNeTU2Utm9srpUjGt17qQ1YdZxTeDzpByGUVDbEAkQxFPmrTllGCuWMJpLnPGBRsafpG7-0rE04bRmz2DtqCzk0YeECi1tQgC4hOxzOoG8t4g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=112872964&ar=4833689&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty259figa1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two spectroscopically observed candidates that turned out to be regular quasars with a nearby interloper. The best estimate J<span class=\"small-caps\">avelin</span> time delays are \u22122\u2009d (top) and 15\u2009d (bottom).</p></div></div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div data</a>\r\n            </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n        <h2 scrollto-destination=\"supplementary-data\"  id=\"supplementary-data\" class=\"section-title\">Supplementary data</h2>\r\n        <div class=\"dataSuppLink\"><a href=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/476/1/10.1093_mnras_sty259/1/sty259_supp.txt?Expires=1611466180&amp;Signature=0JdQgQd8eV3c-vdsECDnxtEN1Oigit7~8by-6fBxecWhARM4U2ulvqlut3Y6XNuT1F4D5-Z3Y~mvLpRfd0OLiJdQQU6g8zpxx8YD69vZ5DRRVMhIZwP4x1WpyU09jVttNLK2GNlyOZ~nsl98~TZ19dP5N-gx3G8jyfAIg0De8VhbhQ52bY39hHcDlE~Xxlw-EsQnbxFEzBcFlKnCjdmmeJmY4C1MjvW4lVnY6H7CSvARe4FJr4DCIMAp~WpiRwRUoUBcfQFk1akqMx8~-T8UakYhJEX20AziAjrElSUTg8BS5otBUTi2QqKyEmAlK7AlZbatQTpSOzCGRUUf7NwcFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\"><span class=\"label\">Supplemental material</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Supplementary data are available at <em><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/mnras/sty259#supplementary-data\" target=\"_blank\">MNRAS</a></em> online.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><strong>Table3_online.txt</strong></p></div></a> - txt file</div>\r\n \n    </div>\n                    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleDataRepositories "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018MNRAS.476..663K", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Incomplete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "We report the discovery of a new gravitationally lensed quasar (double) from the Optical Gravitational Lensing Experiment (OGLE) identified inside the \u223c670deg<SUP>2</SUP> area encompassing the Magellanic Clouds. The source was selected as one of \u223c60 `red W1 - W2' mid-infrared objects from WISE and having a significant amount of variability in OGLE for both two (or more) nearby sources. This is the first detection of a gravitational lens, where the discovery is made `the other way around', meaning we first measured the time delay between the two lensed quasar images of -132 &lt; t<SUB>AB</SUB> &lt; -76 d (90 per cent CL), with the median t<SUB>AB</SUB> \u2248 -102 d (in the observer frame), and where the fainter image B lags image A. The system consists of the two quasar images separated by 1.5 arcsec on the sky, with I \u2248 20.0 mag and I \u2248 19.6 mag, respectively, and a lensing galaxy that becomes detectable as I \u2248 21.5 mag source, 1.0 arcsec from image A, after subtracting the two lensed images. Both quasar images show clear AGN broad emission lines at z = 2.16 in the New Technology Telescope spectra. The spectral energy distribution (SED) fitting with the fixed source redshift provided the estimate of the lensing galaxy redshift of z \u2248 0.9 \u00b1 0.2 (90 per cent CL), while its type is more likely to be elliptical (the SED-inferred and lens-model stellar mass is more likely present in ellipticals) than spiral (preferred redshift by the lens model).", "start_page": "663", "authors": ["Kostrzewa-Rutkowska, Zuzanna", "Koz\u0142owski, Szymon", "Lemon, Cameron", "Anguita, T.", "Greiner, J.", "Auger, M. K.", "Soszy\u0144ski, I.", "Poleski, R.", "Pietrukowicz, P.", "Skowron, J.", "Mr\u00f3z, P.", "Ulaczyk, K.", "Pawlak, M."], "issn": "0035-8711", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1801.08481", "Title": "A gravitationally lensed quasar discovered in OGLE", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: observational", "quasars: general", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "volume": "476", "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018MNRAS.476..663K", "end_page": "672", "number": "1", "publication_year": "2018/05/1", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/sty259", "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "author_address": ["AA(SRON, Netherlands Institute for Space Research, Sorbonnelaan 2, NL-3584 CA Utrecht, the Netherlands; Department of Astrophysics/IMAPP, Radboud University Nijmegen, PO Box 9010, NL-6500 GL Nijmegen, the Netherlands; Warsaw University Astronomical Observatory, Al.
